div1.p: Every line of your letter is perfectly plain to me.

I quite appreciate the necessity for gathering in the loose shekels. It is reasonable that you should write for whoever will pay you best. Personally, I rather lean toward the coin, and have a strong affection for the jingle of dough in the hip pocket, — I can even stand it in the vest pocket, inside or out.

I never read a story of yours in my life that I didn't think came spontaneously from you, and I know how difficult it will be for you to write, any time in your existence, a particular story to suit particular requirements. You know that when you do turn out a Munsey story you will have no difficulty placing it here.

I am certain you will win a position for yourself among American writers, and when that time comes, I shall be quite content with the knowledge that I knew you before the great American mob, — and that's quite enough.

Now tell me exactly where this cabin in the Black Hills is. How do you get there and do you really mean that if I should come you would play the phonograph in my ear? How I want to know particularly about this, because it will have considerable effect on my reply.

Glad the book is coming out on the 25th. I will do my best to whoop it up for you. Moreover, I shall achieve
16
certain results in that direction that will astonish you.

Give my best wishes to your mother, and assure her that the time is not far away when she shall be amply rewarded for the long nights she spent leaning over her curly-headed boy, speculating on the ultimate.
